+Sky Tower It's generally just being unable to turn thoughts into actions 
and mostly regarding long term rewards or consequences (vs immediately 
gratifying acts, which is part of why we are impulsive- impulsive acts are 
usually immediately gratifying). Ever hear of that marshmallow experiment 
with those kids, where they would put 1 in front of them and say that if 
they waited to eat it after 10 minutes they can get a second marshmallow? 
Someone with ADHD, metaphorically speaking, will take the single 
marshmallow nearly every time even if they wanted to wait and get a second 
one. We usually can't help it, and when we do it makes us tired and we feel 
far more mentally exerted than a normal person.

And then of course someone with hyperactivity literally has grown a part of 
their brain too fast, and the rest of their understandably immature brain 
can't handle the more mature part, and so they are restless and can't 
contain themselves.

comments.text:
+Reshma Mohan I have Borderline myself, and something that I have found 
very useful is Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT).  It is a type of therapy 
that was developed specifically for people with Borderline.  I recommend 
looking for a therapist that specializes in DBT, preferably at a clinic 
that has DBT groups.  DBT groups teach skills over a one year period (at 
least where I live), and it's really helpful to get feedback from the 
counselors and other patients in the group.  DBT teaches how to be more 
aware of your emotions (like recognizing rage long before it hits you and 
carries you away), interact with others, handle distressing situations, 
etc.  This website has a pretty good overview of what DBT looks like: 
http://www.dbtselfhelp.com/

comments.text:
+Sven T. Omission of psychopathy from the DSM does not make the observed 
traits of this classification disappear. There are still other diagnostic 
tools being used outside of the DSM (mostly outside of north america) that 
do still use the term, so you can't say this classification doesn't exist. 
Calling it outdated is fair, but the term and concept are still in use and 
very much do exist. If someone self identifies as a psychopath I do 
question the validity of this claim as it is likely self diagnosed.  

So far as I've studied the main reason the term is generally used in 
education (not clinical use) is to highlight the distinction in concepts 
between "born that way" (psycopathy) and "conditioned that way" 
(sociopathy).
comments.author: Anthony Sterr

comments.text:
Not picking sides, but depending on what country you are from, the terms 
are different. Last time I checked, the UK veers more towards psychopath 
and in some cases considers sociopath to possibly be the "higher end" of 
that spectrum (less inhibition and/or impulse control/etc), and the US uses 
ASPD and does not consider psychopath to be a word with concrete definition 
(note: all countries do not use the DSM, agree on the DSM, etc). And to 
correct Crossark (no offense), but not all sadists are serial killers, nor 
are plenty of people on the ASPD spectrum with sadistic tendencies or 
sadistic sexuality (I'm stating these as separate things because they often 
are) non-consensual and/or serial killers or even abusers. That would be 
labeling people with ASPD with sadistic tendencies to be incapable of the 
ability to thrive/cope in generalized society in the sense of respecting 
boundaries due to inevitable repercussions, which is a rude assumption. 
Sadly it's assumption a lot of people make because of a greater portion of 
those studied with ASPD, because a large part of the populace with ASPD 
choose to not step forward and speak up about it due to stigma/etc.

Like I said, not attempting to rub anyone the wrong way, nor am i looking 
for internet drama (which is annoying). But talking about ASPD (or any 
other term any other region or social structure may use for it) like it is 
black and white is ignorant of the fact that it's a) a spectrum disorder 
and b) plenty of people with it learn to live quite comfortably without 
having to go to grandiose extremes.

Not responding back past this point. Anyone wanting to talk ASPD further 
can just message me if they'd like :)

I feel you +Dewald Louw Still I ask, what is normal? The researchers that 
create these labels, if they defined what normal is, less than 99 percent 
of the population would fit the criteria. The researchers use objective 
methods with their own interest in mind, without considering the personal 
experience of the “subject.” Arguably, millions of people go about their 
daily lives coping with “distress” because the cause/s of that distress are 
considered “normal” (then they develop dependencies; caffeine, nicotine, 
alcohol abuse, chronic masturbation, etc.). Researchers should more often 
consider the environments that give rise to these “personality disorders.” 
They might begin to notice a pattern (dehumanization, oppression, 
competition, etc.). One of my students has a guardian follow him around all 
day because of “behavioral” issues; he’s a jewel in my class. However, a 
few of the other kids in my class seem to have less control of their 
behavior and no guardian. Regardless, everyone is different in their own 
right with different personalities respectably. In the end, people should 
be understood and embraced; not judged, degraded, and singled out as 
abnormal,

top_comment.text:
While mental illness is awful, I don't think that is absolves people of 
responsibility for their actions. Re: question below of what's the 
difference between being an asshole and having a personality disorder? To 
me, not sure that there is. If you treat people like shit AND you have a 
personality disorder, well, does that mean it's not your fault that you 
treat people like shit? No. People with certain personalities disorders 
(those exhibiting psychotic symptoms aside) know exactly what they're 
doing, even if they know it's wrong and "wish they could stop". That's why 
they can be incarcerated for their actions and are legally fit to stand 
trial.

I dated a guy with BPD, who knew he had a problem (and had self-diagnosed), 
but hadn't sought treatment. He mostly certainly would fit the diagnosis. 
Obsessed with achieving success, with being perfect, was incredibly jealous 
that I had dated people before him and that I had been in love before, made 
me feel so awful about it, twisted everything to make it seem like it was 
my fault... would flip his shit if he felt like he was being slighted in 
any way... it was absolutely awful and truly abusive. I think he hated 
himself for it, though. After an outburst, he would talk to me about it and 
say that he KNOWS that he's overreacting, but can't help that those are the 
emotions he feels in those circumstances. He's trying to teach himself how 
to override those initial aggressive responses. But regardless of his 
efforts, and despite the fact that I consider myself a strong, confident 
woman, by the end of our ONLY TWO MONTH relationship, I felt so small, so 
trapped, so scared of upsetting him, so scared of leaving him for fear he 
might threaten to kill himself. Do I have sympathy for the fact that he 
finds it so hard to relate normally to people and that he had an awful 
upbringing that likely lead to his personality disorder? Of course. But at 
the end of the day, he is the one who was emotionally abusive, and is 
responsible for his actions. I hope he gets the help that he needs. Therapy 
can be very successful in teaching those with BPD how to better regulate 
and handle their intense emotions.﻿
top_comment.author: Lindsey Cowie

comments.text:
+Lindsey Cowie 
Personally I believe it is a case by case determination of the situation in 
question, & how the person or persons in question respective mental 
characteristics effect the outcome of the scenario, that determine the 
level of culpability both ethically & legally.

Allow me to provide you with some perspective, when I was child a speeding 
driver nearly struck my sister, struck my dog (a black lab of decent size) 
with such force that it was nearly ripped in two, & kept right on driving 
even as my sister was screaming at the carnage.

I felt no concern for the physical safety of my sister, nor for her 
emotional distress. I felt no anger or hostility toward the driver for 
nearly killing a relative nor for killing my dog. & I didn't feel sadness 
or distress for the death of my dog. What I did feel was annoyance at the 
idea of having to clean up the mess, as I didn't feel like spending the 
afternoon scraping up roadkill & digging a hole to bury it.

However, the rest of the family was predictably emotional, so when I 
feigned being very distressed at the whole affair they naturally believed 
me; & the task was passed to another, leaving me free to enjoy the 
afternoon as I saw fit. I didn't give my dog a second thought.

 I used duplicity & manipulation of people's emotional state to achieve a 
desired end result, & I am fully responsible for those actions, as I knew 
exactly what I was doing when I was doing it.

However, I am not responsible for not feeling the emotions that a *"normal 
person"* feels under those circumstances. Asking someone like me to feel 
those things, is like asking a blind person to sort your crayons according 
to color. Simply put, it is an absurdly stupid action.

As to the whole *"mental illness is awful"* number, I would say it depends 
upon the person. Personally I rather like being the way I am, I am 
unencumbered by a great many things that seem to bother most of the people 
around me. The most taxing thing for me is when I need to *"play normal"* 
for the sake of certain interpersonal interactions.

comments.text:
I believe my mother has BPD. She always thinks she's the victim, and 
everyone else is either bad, evil, and cruel, or the best person in the 
world (black and white thinking), and she truly believes everything bad and 
terrible in her life is somehow someone else's fault and never hers. She 
also never apologises, and the times when she has to, she *never* means it; 
she makes one feel as though she's placating you and one is forcing her to 
apologise against her will and proving true her thoughts about one being a 
cruel, unforgiving, and ungrateful person.

Everyone she knows (she hardly has any friends and she isn't very close to 
her family) believes she's the best and most loving and caring mother there 
is, and so many people, from family members to school teachers have told me 
that I am very lucky to have her and that I should take care of her (she 
usually remembers only that part).

She can be quite charming, and one of her biggest obsessions is her image 
and what others know of her. She always makes sure that others think she is 
nothing but happy and that she has not a problem in her life, even though 
that's far from reality, because she believes being honest about her 
shortcomings will make her seem weak and vulnerable and give others who 
hate her a reason to be happy - no one hates her, though; she's the one 
hating people she doesn't like for no reason and any reason, and she's the 
one who takes such joy at the misfortune of her 'enemies'. She always 
denies that, but you can tell that's not true when she's suddenly happy, 
active, and in such a good mood.

She also lies quite a lot effortlessly. Even when she's aware that you've 
found out that she's been lying and making up stories and excuses to get 
what she wanted at the time, whether it's perpetual passive quiet and peace 
or your own money, you can't outright say to her that she lied or even 
imply it, because she'll play the victim again whom no one believes or 
wants to trust, and she'll make sure to let you know exactly how bad and 
disappointing a person and a child you are and have always been to her all 
along, and that it's typical of you.

She becomes absolutely crazy and hysterical when you try to explain 
something wasn't your fault or inadvertently make her feel sort of 
incompetent or at fault.

She always thinks she is an incompetent person and mother and a failure, 
and she will tell you that she is that for no reason and at no provocation 
whatsoever as though she's trying to guilt you into doing something she 
wants (many times she won't tell you what that is, because she simply hates 
your very existence in her life) and tell you she knows that you think of 
her as an incompetent person, and she'll probably go on for another hour 
feigning weakness and apologising as if she's capitulating and agreeing 
with your imagined cruel and inconsiderate remarks about her, even when 
none of that is remotely true or justifiable and there's no reason for her 
to believe that - it's like she's constantly looking to set you off and 
have a never-ending argument with you so she can blame you for *everything* 
and anything and ask whoever else is around to save her from the evil 
person that you are who's always fighting with her.

She's also very insecure, and the thought of others abandoning her can make 
her turn into a very obnoxious, bitter, defensive, and unsupportive person 
(even and especially to me, her only son).

She also believes she always knows best and knows what's best for her 
children, which makes her very controlling, patronising, and dismissive in 
such an obnoxious way, and makes her think she has the right to make 
decisions for you and to make sure you're not always available to other 
people or in very close relationships—intimate or otherwise—with anyone, 
which I think only shows how insecure and immature she is and that she 
really has no respect for anyone and isn't comfortable with those close to 
her becoming independent and not making her always feel important and 
needed, as she likes; she considers every step one takes into autonomy and 
self-dependence to be a solid statement about how she's incompetent and 
that you don't want her in your life, which is ridiculous and makes 
maintaining the relationship while going about one's life and other 
important things like work and studies even more difficult and absolutely 
tiresome.

She can be extremely abusive and hurtful verbally and carelessly say the 
worst and most hurtful things a mother could possibly utter, and the things 
they say are usually well-thought-out and too relevant and germane to be 
random, and they often offer explanations for how she had been treating 
you. She usually says these stuff with a strange, sort of evil smile on her 
face, which makes her seem like nothing short of a sadistic narcissist. Try 
to imagine how distressing and confusing having one's mother pray before 
one's eyes for one's death and curse the day that you were born at an age 
as young as 9, like she's purely and utterly evil and never was your mother 
for a day. There were times when I seriously doubted I was her son, even 
though many people said I look like her. When you bring up what she said to 
you and told you the night before, first, she will act all upset and 
disappointed as though you're trying to spoil her good mood and fight with 
her on that fine morning, then, she will blame it all on you and claim you 
were the one who made her angry, which, in her mind, somehow justifies the 
cruel things she said to you and wished upon you and will most likely say 
to you again at anothe time. One thing you can be sure she won't do is to 
sincerely apologise to you and show you any remorse. No, she'll either try 
such stupid and immature things as tickling you with a playful smile on so 
as to try to make you laugh and prove that you're not really mad or 
anything, or she will act like a victim, say sorry, and look to you as if 
you are cruel and forcing her to do things against her will.

She also threatens to kill herself quite often, sometimes with using 
whatever inflammable liquid close by and a light, and a few times she's 
torn off her shirts in her tantrums when she was under pressure and being 
confronted into an uncomfortable situation where she is, indeed, the one at 
fault and she couldn't escape or come up with an excuse and had to admit 
she, indeed, was mistaken or that she had been lying and that it wasn't my 
fault. That's her last resort. She may also get dressed in hours and leave 
home for an hour and return claiming she'd nearly been run over by a car or 
a bus or that she fell over on her face in the middle of the street and 
people helped her up. Only her clothes never looked dirty or creased when 
she returned any of those times and there were no bruises on her face.

She believes no one understands her, loves her, or cares genuinely about 
her. She also feels very entitled to your time and attention and entitled 
to have money and everything "other people have and enjoy," even though 
she's unemployed and has never worked for more than a year in her life and 
has of her own will given up two jobs, both very respectable and at 
government institutions. Both times she felt her older and more experienced 
co-workers were jealous of her (she was dandy and stylish at the time) and 
could somehow harm her in a way or turn others against her, but I suspect 
that's her being paranoid.
Being jobless while other women she sees (and envies and detests) are 
confident, independent, and successful in their lives is another reason 
she's convinced she's incompetent and that people, even her family and 
children, hate her and don't respect her.
She whines and complains all the time, and she's an expert at feigning 
weakness of any and all sorts. She's quite a burden.

One of my sisters has OCD and bipolar and dependent personality disorders 
and the other—the eldest one—is narcissistic. The eldest has always been 
her favourite child, the Good Child or the Hero. My eldest sister has 
always acted as her hand, brain, and tongue. She has been physically and 
verbally abusive to her only brother and I've always found her quite 
intimidating, unpredictable, and sometimes utterly cruel and sadistic, and 
my mother, being a naturally timid person, found in her aggressive and 
assertive daughter her missing half which she was right to feel made her 
invincible and complete.

Unfortunately, I've seen my sister do the same unapologetically to my 
4-year-old nephew and 10-months-old niece, her children. She thinks her 
little children, especially my sweet and amazing nephew, should know right 
from wrong and should only do as she orders them and not embarrass her in 
front of her family or strangers.

She also believes that good children never do what "they know" will upset 
their mother, such as jumping and running around in the apartment where 
they're forced to live (this and the following is especially true for my 
nephew), crying (weeping), shouting, interrupting while the adults are 
talking, demanding that they get that expensive toy while at the store, 
asking for food and then leaving it intact, and even farting. She believes 
if children behave "badly," it isn't the mother's fault but their own, and 
beating and screaming at them, taking away their toys, and leaving them all 
alone at home will teach them a lesson that they need to learn.

I've been through everything my nephew has faced so far and the things he 
will certainly face when I leave the country. I've told my mother about 
this, and that I think this is her fault because she encouraged that 
behaviour in her daughter from the very beginning when she didn't have the 
patience or ability to get hold of me as a kid, and I've had to fight with 
my sister when she came to visit a couple months ago and be the one to 
speak about it while my other sister and mother scream at me in anger 
rather than help me, and that was only out of my concern for the future of 
my young nephew and niece.

I can't depend on my mother or my sister because they fear her, and I 
believe my sister was shocked and felt almost too intimidated to find that 
I was no longer afraid of her and was willing and able to stand up to her, 
after so many years of crying as a helpless little child and of being 
slapped, beaten, dragged, burned with matches, and forcibly fed chilli 
pepper all before my mother.

When I let her know for the first time that I remember exactly what she did 
and how she treated me as a child, she simply said I deserved it because I 
would cry and ask for toys that were too expensive and embarrass them at 
stores, or run and play around in the apartment with a soccer ball, disturb 
our neighbour, and cause them trouble—but we were talking about a type-1 
diabetic child who has been to amusement parks only three times in his life 
and has never played any sports, joined any sports clubs like all of his 
friends, or been able/good enough to play soccer or learn to swim or play a 
musical instrument at his schools in Cairo. She said my trying to play in 
the apartment was wrong and unjustified, and that I was not entitled to *any 
one* of those things which I said is the least a child like my nephew 
deserves.

I believe my borderline mother is also somewhat passive-aggressive. My 
absentee father is passive-aggressive. She hasn't been diagnosed or been to 
a psychiatrist, unlike my bipolar sister with OCD. When I tell her that she 
has BPD (and after I explain what that is), she takes it as an insult. I've 
found that there's no point in discussing this with her (or with my bipolar 
sister), anyway.

I have a life of my own to start and live, and I want it to be as normal 
and healthy as possible, and it's going to be away from my mother and, 
regrettably, from my dear nephew and niece, whom I'm going to miss. I'm a 
non-believing Muslim-born Egyptian who's renounced the one and only 
religion of peace, and I'm going to Australia (by plane, not by boat) to 
seek asylum there by the end of this year. Won't be able to return even if 
I wanted to, and I will be going to college in the US and I will be busy 
working and saving so that I may take the LSAT and go to law school after 
graduation. I will pay my father every penny he's worked to give me since 
I've turned 18, and I'm very thankful to him for his help.

When I get harassed, intimidated, and threatened on the phone by the police 
and the government monitors my Facebook and Twitter accounts and stores 
everything I've written despite my having deleted it, I do have no option 
but to flee, and the least thing I should expect from my mother is to 
support me morally and not hold me back, make me feel guilty and pressure

prison at this point and find myself alongside terrorists and murderers and 
getting raped for no crime. She says it's only out of concern for what may

and more unwilling to 'sacrifice' anything than I am.

comments.text:
I would disagree to a certain degree.  We don't morally condemn someone for 
something they had little to no moral agency over.  I would say that some 
mental diseases are worse than other.  However, given the subjectivity of 
diagnoses of these mental conditions, I could see how it seems important to 
stop any criminal from simply pleasing insanity after committing an 
atrocity.  What you seem to emphasize is a consequentialist morality. 
 Regardless of whether you had legitimate evil intentions to kill someone, 
you still killed them, and should be punished accordingly.  I find some 
issue with this, for, often times, consequences are driven by external 
factors--not purely human choice.  Take this example: imagine two identical 
situations in which a person goes to the bar, gets drunk, and decides to 
drive home.  In the first situation, they get home without harming 
themselves or anybody else.  However, in the second scenario, a child just 
happens to be crossing the road as the person speeds past.  They end up 
killing the child.  Both drunk drivers made the same choice(with similarly 
blurred judgement).  The circumstances of their environment determined the 
consequences of those choices.  Should the second driver be punished *more* 
for something they couldn't control?

Drawing a connection to the question at hand, should a person with a fully 
clear mind who decides to murder someone and a person with a delusion 
convincing them that they need to kill someone who kills someone be treated 
and punished the same?  It might not absolve the person with a mental 
disability of *all* of their responsibility/agency, but it seems like those 
are two very different situations.

comments.text:
People with chronic disorders/disabilities, either physical or mental, live 
with them every. single. day. We cannot escape it. We can treat it (if 
there are treatments), but it never goes away. Every day is another day of 
living as an ill person. It affects our lives, our relationships, our 
schoolwork, our jobs, everything. We are constantly reminded by society 
that we are Not Normal and face differing levels of ostracization from 
able-bodied, neurotypical people. Often we have to explain to others why we 
can't function at 100% and being outright about our problems is less 
energy-consuming than being secretive, internalized, and ashamed about it.
Also, I am queer and to be honest, I see very little difference between 
someone complaining about people being open and accepting of their mental 
illness as a reality and someone saying "I have no problem with gay people, 
but like why do they wear it like a badge and be open about it in public 
ugh".
So like, God forbid we accept our disorders as a part of us and be open 
about our illnesses.

comments.text:
+alienzen That is an interesting view point. It is possible for some people 
to get misdiagnosed or not diagnosed at all for a personality disorder. 
People who have BPD are actually one of those groups who are under 
diagnosed. When someone who has BPD acts as the "victim" as you so phrased 
it there are many times they are not even aware of their behavior and how 
it can be ineffective. I'm studying DBT and physcology right now hoping to 
work specifically with BPD patients. There is still a lot of research that 
has to happen on the disorder. There is also a lot of stigma surrounding it 
and misinformation. Marsha Linehan is actually one of the leading people 
making break throughs with BPD. She developed DBT which is the therapy most 
proven to help BPD patients. There are also studies they have done on 
brains of people who suffer from BPD they are learning that their brains 
are not functioning like a healthy brain. There are some parts that can be 
over active or under. They are also finding out that they may not have the 
"brakes" so to speak in the pre frontal cortex that stops the negative or 
impulsive thoughts which could attribute to impulsive behavior and angry 
outburst. They still have a mental illness and it is just as serious as a 
physical illness such as cancer. Marsha Linehan describes their emotional 
sensitivity as if they have no emotional skin. If you touch a burn patient 
with no skin they will jump at the lightest of touches compared to someone 
who has skin. It's a hard illness to see people struggle through. The 
majority of people I have gotten to work with who have BPD were aware there 
was something wrong or not quite right with them. Receiving the diagnosis 
of BPD came as a great relief to them. There is the other side to that as 
well because of the stigma that surrounds it still there were some who were 
in denial about it because of the inaccurate information or hate sites you 
find online. People who suffer from BPD tend to be more empathetic. There 
are expectations to every rule and the vast majority feel regret if they 
hurt someone and with the right treatment they become very skillful living 
normal lives and are able to manage their intense feelings. Men are very 
under diagnosed and women go undiagnosed as well not to the same extent but 
they do. There is still not enough awareness and knowledge out there to 
help people who suffer from BPD get the treatment they need. If you ever 
care to see what it's like living with BPD Marsha Linehan helped with a 
documentary it's on YouTube it's called "Back from the Edge." It is very 
sad because those who suffer from BPD are at a greater risk of committing 
suicide. Thanks for your time.

comments.text:
Powerthrucontrol has that correct--there are males who do not get diagnosed 
as BPD when they should, but are incorrectly diagnosed with ASPD instead. 
Part of the problem (and they have only really began to uncover this in the 
last ten years or so) is that men and women display different behaviors and 
symptoms. The way a woman with BPD acts is well known and usually 
recognized after some time for observation. The pattern a male uses is a 
bit different and in some ways more subtle, and thus it often gets 
misdiagnosed as something else down the line, often ASPD but sometimes 
other cluster B personality disorders (both Narcissistic and Histrionic). 

As for why women get diagnosed with ASPD less, this actually may have a 
genetic root to it--a long, complex discussion to have, but I'll summarize 
it up with just saying that men are more genetically predisposed to this 
disorder than women, though women can show this trait as well. As with BPD, 
women sometimes show different traits than men, which makes it harder to 
diagnose and recognize. Men tend to be more aggressive and thus more likely 
to act out with violence, and violent history is often a contributing 
factor to diagnosis. People with ASPD however, are not necessarily violent, 
as is the case with a lot of women with ASPD--they may have no empathy or 
regard for others and little ability to follow social norms, but they don't 
go out of their way to hurt people. Also, someone with ASPD get incorrectly 
diagnosed with BPD.

Personality disorders are both fascinating and frustrating in learning 
about them and trying to understand them--there is definitely still a great 
deal of work to be done in getting better at recognizing and diagnosing 
them, as well as understanding causes and origins, which helps contribute 
to treatment development.

comments.text:
+Alicia en el pais de las maravillas  However, everybody has quirks and 
relationships are not just for the one in a million semi-perfect person, if 
this person even exists. You don't owe the world perfection.

As long as you are honest about your condition when starting into a 
relationship, it is very possible for you to have a long term stable 
relationship. Your BPD will act up once in while and the occasional 
explosion will happen, but as long you and your partner can put those 
explosions into context, that is something that can be handled. 

Enough guys even enjoy a little bit of drama, especially when it comes to 
long term relationships. They, long term relationships that is, suffer more 
often from too little excitement than too much of it. 

It really boils down to whether or not you meet someone you fall in love 
with, or for whome you have romantic feelings, or whatever you want to call 
it. If that is to happen, throw out of the window what Disney constructed 
as the relationship prototype and go for it.  

It also doesn't *have* to be long term. If a relationship for you means to 
go on a rollercoaster for a month and then to close this ride behind you, 
that is fine as well. 

Missing out on love and sex because you fear you ought to be a more stable 
person to enjoy those things would a dire sacrifice to make. 

Your degree of self-reflection alone and the intelligence radiating from 
that already show that some episodes of crazy are a worthy prize to pay to 
be with you.

top_comment.text: People who cut are really stupid﻿
top_comment.author: The lightning dragon

comments.text: +18807BB that was a good one
comments.author: The lightning dragon

comments.text:
As a personal anecdote, I have only come across three types of cutters: 
Masochists who enjoy being hurt (some sex shops even cater to those who cut 
for pleasure, at least where I live they do), people who are extremely 
depressed and feel like almost all of their control of their lives is gone 
and the only things they have control over now are whether or not they hurt 
themselves and whether or not they live or die, and those who use cutting 
as a way to ground themselves so they can stop anxiety attacks and such 
from getting worse. So it is used for pleasure, a feeling of control, and 
as a maladaptive coping mechanism.

The first one is none of your business. If you don't like it and think it's 
stupid, then don't be a sub. Or better yet, stay clear of the BDSM 
community.

The second one is someone who is extremely depressed. For whatever reason, 
whether it is because of a genetic predisposition and/or traumatic events 
that caused them to be depressed, this person feels as if the only things 
they have any control over are whether they hurt themselves in someway and 
whether they live or die. By calling them stupid, you are kicking them when 
they are down—down almost as far as someone can go. It is hard to think of 
things more arrogant than kicking someone who is that far down. They need 
help, not to be told they are stupid, not to be shamed.

Lastly, the third one is someone who surely has problems. They could have 
anxiety, depression, paranoia, and/or problems dissociating. The cutting is 
just a maladaptive coping mechanism. They need help. They don't need to be 
shamed by people. They need help so they can learn coping mechanisms that 
aren't maladaptive. If someone has a habit of using a maladaptive coping 
mechanism when they have a problem and they do this for years, then it can 
be very hard to break said habit, but adding shame will only make it worse. 
These people need help, not hostility. They need love, not hate. They need 
support, not shame.
comments.author: Dawnofthehead

comments.text:
+( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) harmonicdoge ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) No, there is a difference. I remember 
reading about it somewhere as being along the lines that the difference 
between the two is: firstly, social anxiety is just one symptom among 
several with AvPD; secondly, a person with social anxiety is always looking 
at how others react to him/her and getting insecure about it, whereas a 
person with AvPD is also looking at how he/she himself/herself reacts to 
others' reactions to him/her and *also* at how others react to his/her 
reactions to himself/herself.... So it creates a kind of feedback loop 
which can get out of hand. Also, a social phobic, while insecure about how 
they appear to others, may still believe themselves to be likeable people 
worthy of friendship and love, whereas avoidants really have serious 
self-esteem issues and have to struggle to convince themselves that they're 
"good enough" to do something as simple as, well, this act of typing a 
comment here for example: we're hard-wired to expect people to hate us or 
to get angry at us. So...a lot of the time we just bottle everything up, or 
we go to the opposite extreme and go out of our way to piss others off so 
that at least we're in control of their rejection of us. It's pretty messed 
up and not a nice way to live.
"IN FACT social anxiety and avoidant have about a 60% co-morbidity 
rate!"Very, very true — and I'm glad you brought it up: as I said, a 
certain degree of social anxiety is like a symptom of AvPD anyway, and if 
it really gets out of hand then it can become a disorder in its own 
right in someone who has AvPD, which is how it is for me.Incidentally, did 
you know that a lot of AvPD sufferers (including myself) are also 
agoraphobic? It makes sense: we're highly-strung individuals at the best of 
times, somewhat hypersensitive, and that ties in with the fact that many of 
us are easily overloaded by sensory stimulation; there's even a theory I've 
read about along the lines that it's linked to issues with things like 
balance and proprioception and spatial awareness and so forth so that the 
world "out there" appears more overwhelming for us than for most people. 
Especially in crowds or in public places with lots of people walking about. 
That makes sense to me since as a child I was pretty uncoordinated and 
clumsy and even now I carry a lifelong self-perception of being physically 
awkward (even though in reality I'm not *that* bad). So in my mind I equate 
such environment with the idea of being an accident waiting to happen and 
that kind of reinforces my fears in other ways too.

top_comment.text: How do you change your mindset if you understand your problem? ﻿
top_comment.author: F13RY0N5L4UGHT

comments.text:
DBT, CBT, and ACT are all good places to start, but they work best for 
different issues. DBT works for self-harm, suicidal ideation, and substance 
abuse. In fact, DBT was originally created to treat BPD. CBT works well for 
many different things: a few different personality disorders, depression, 
anxiety, eating disorders, schizophrenia, substance abuse, PTSD, body 
dysmorphic disorder, and many other things, too. ACT has been shown to work 
with addiction, depression, anxiety, psychosis, self-harm, body 
dissatisfaction, eating disorders, and a few other things. The best way to 
find out what would work best for you is to find a therapist and see what 
they recommend for you after they've reviewed your symptoms.
comments.author: Dawnofthehead

Also, I've yet to see *one* comment on this video of somebody sharing a 
disorder they have and having anything but negative feelings towards it. 
People don't admit to having problems to show off, they do it for many 
reasons. *Some* do it for attention, *some* do it to manipulate, while 
*most* do it do genuinely share their condition as a human. You're opinions 
are extremely judgmental and prejudicial.
comments.author: elementface

comments.text:
+(Φ▿▿Φ)Ψ Sorry I just couldn't get through all of that. Try using 
paragraphs next time.

As I believe I said before, I am not shitting on those that genuinely have 
problems. But those people are fewer and further between and also are a lot 
less likely to even want to admit their problems in public, let alone brag 
about them.
comments.author: Livid Imp

comments.text:
+Livid Imp "Because mental illness is FUN now."Depends on the disorder and 
the symptom(s). I'm not going to pretend that *everything* that society 
can't handle about me sucks for me personally."Gives you something to talk 
to strangers about so they won't (accurately) suspect what a dull little 
automaton you really are."I tried to be a dull little automaton once but it 
was hard because at 37 years old and with official diagnoses that took 9 
months of weekly sessions to receive back in the mid-late '90s (before 
everyone had the Internet and could diagnose themselves no less), I was 
already well on my way to Gonzo Land when I decided that a local Taoist 
temple was the best place to conduct spontaneous wrestling matches with a 
friend and when I realised that the snack food isle in the local Woolworths 
was a great place to sit cross-legged on the floor while chillaxing and 
contemplating the fact that a funky-looking lightning bolt in the sky was a 
sign that I needed to figure out how to build a real life version of one of 
those cartoon robots that's made of vehicles/mechanical animals that join 
together (I never did quite figure it out — and 200 million dollars is an 
awful lot of money to try to figure out how to make)."That guy who lives 
downtown with the tinfoil hat and the shopping cart, screaming at his 
penis...that guy doesn't tell anyone that he is mentally ill."Thanks for 
sharing that little bit of info about yourself, even if you did resort to 
doing it in the third person. Does your penis ever scream back? (j/k)"If 
you think I am being hyperbolic, do a search for any personality disorder 
video on YouTube and check the comments.  These people seem more like they 
are auditioning for the next Lifetime movie of the week than 'suffering' 
with a illness."To an extent I actually agree with you. There's a lot of 
garden variety pseudo-insanity out there. A lot of 'em come across like 
"the worried well", i.e. people who worry themselves into thinking they're 
unwell but really they just suck. So they go to these shrinks and it's 
like, within an hour or two, "Oh yes, you definitely have [insert name of 
disorder here]!" and then it's like "Here's a prescription for [whatever 
brain-damaging drug]! Have a nice day! Bye! [GLEEFULLY RUBS HANDS TOGETHER 
BECAUSE THEY'VE SCORED ANOTHER ONE FOR BIG PHARMA]." I'll take my legit 
full-blown magical thinking about fairies in the garden and dragons in the 
sky and coco bananas ideas over their boring shit any day, as long as I 
don't turn into a total schizophrenic 'cause that would suck to the max.
comments.author: (Φ▿▿Φ)Ψ

talking with, had been asked about it or if it would be noticed but taken 
in the wrong way.

Yep those kinds of people annoy me a bit too but as long as those people 
who brag about having disorders have no actual disorders or even if they do 
as long as they're taken care of along with the ones who actually have, 
everything is going to be okay. Nobody deserves to have a disorder and

Shut up meg.
comments.author: Wilford Brimley

comments.text:
+Tom Tyler
I think you might be talking about Livid Imp's comment, not mine.  Still, 
though, I know what you mean.  I think that everyone who struggles, (all of 
us, to different degrees), does have the right to some sympathy if they 
want it.  The degree of sympathy they're entitled to is based on the 
severity of the struggles.  (So, yes, everyone is entitled so some 
sympathy, some more than others).  I think the problem with people saying 
they have a mental illness when they don't is that they get more sympathy 
then they are entitle to for whatever mental quirk they think they have, 
and that, in a way, undermines those who have actual, serious mental 
illnesses.
comments.author: FlyingPiper13

Your comment about a "need to feel special" is very salient. Particularly 
in the kind of white, privileged suburbanites described. With social media 
available as, essentially, mouthpieces of narcissism nowadays (*ahem*

sympathy for their struggles.

People like to share and discuss their problems. It's not weird or 
attention-seeking, they're just trying to share their experience and maybe 
find other people with the disorder.
comments.author: awkwardCrabwalk

comments.text:
+FlyingPiper13
I actually won't disagree with that, and I am not trying to bash those who 
have genuine illnesses.  But if we accepted the sheer number of people 
classified as mentally ill, it would be the norm, not the exception.
comments.author: Livid Imp

comments.text:
I think that the need to feel special may be part of the reason why so many 
people claim to have disorders, but I think it's also the need to feel 
reassured.  Most people have weird quirks that they don't know how to 
explain, and sometimes they can be stressful or even frightening, 
regardless of whether or not they have a disorder.  A diagnosis of a 
recognized disorder may help them feel more normal and secure, by helping 
them explain to themselves why they are the way they are.  Not knowing 
makes people uneasy, and so diagnosing themselves gives them a way to 
accept their weird little quirks, instead of being confused about them.
comments.author: FlyingPiper13

comments.text:
+Meg Ashley
I'm not looking to be admired.  I'm not looking to "get along".  There is 
nothing random about my vitriol.  I call it like I see it, and I am not 
concerned about hurt feelings.  I won't contribute to the "aren't we all 
great" echo chamber.
comments.author: Livid Imp

captions.text:
I can be smooth and charming and slick. I
can make a very confident impression and
it's hard to leave me at a loss for words.

Sometimes I find myself fantasizing about
unlimited success and power, and beauty.

I have repeatedly used deceit to cheat, con,
or defraud others for my personal gain. To

be honest, I don't have much concern for the
feelings of other people, or their suffering.

Doesn't sound like the Hank you know, does
it?

These are all statements from the Self-Assessment
measure for Personality Disorders, that lets

patients describe themselves, ranking each statement
in terms of how accurate they think it is.

To be honest, you can't rely too much on this
kind of self-reporting to assess what we are

talking about today because while some people
who are over-confident or obsessed with power

or downright deceitful might tell you that
they are, there is a certain subset that won't.

Many of the disorders that we have talked
about so far are considered, "ego-dystonic"

meaning that people who have them are aware
that they have a problem and tend to be
distressed by their symptoms.

Like a person with Bipolar Disorder or OCD
generally knows that they have a psychological

condition and they don't like what it does
to them.

But some disorders are trickier then that.
They are "ego-syntonic," the person experiencing

them doesn't necessarily think that they have
a problem and sometimes, they think the problem
is with everyone else.

Personality disorders fall into this category.
These are psychological disorders marked by

inflexible, disruptive, and enduring behavior
patterns that impair social and other functioning
-- whether the sufferer recognizes that or not.

Unlike many other conditions that we've talked
about, personality disorders are often considered

to be chronic and enduring syndromes that
create noticeable problems in life.

And as you can tell from these self assessment
statements, they can range from relatively

harmless displays of narcissism, to a true
and troubling lack of empathy for other people.

Not only can personality disorders be difficult
to diagnose and understand, they can also

be downright scary. Most of the extreme and
severe disorders go by names that you probably

recognize: psychopathy and sociopathy. I'm talking,
like, serial killers here, mob bosses, Vlad the Impaler.

Cultures have been studying human personality
characteristics for thousands of years, but

the concept of personality disorders is a
much newer idea.

Much of our modern classifications of these
disorders are based on the work of German

psychiatrist, Kurt Schneider, who was one
of the earliest researchers into what was

then known as psychopathy and published a
treatise on the study in 1923.

Today, the DSM 5 contains ten distinct personality
disorder diagnoses, grouped into three clusters.

The first cluster, cluster A, includes what
are often labeled simply as "odd" or "eccentric"

personality characteristics. For example,
someone with paranoid personality disorder

may feel a pervasive distrust of others and
be constantly guarded and suspicious while

a person with a schizoid personality disorder
would seem overly aloof and indifferent, showing

no interest in relationships and few emotional
responses.

Cluster B encompasses dramatic emotional or
impulsive personality characteristics. For

example, a narcissistic personality can display
a selfish grandiose sense of self-importance

and entitlement. Meanwhile, a histrionic personality
might seem like they're acting a part to get

attention, even putting themselves at risk
with dramatic, dangerous, and even suicidal

gestures. The behavior of Cluster B can be
truly self-destructive and frightening, and

these disorders are often associated with
frequent hospitalization.

Finally, Cluster C encompasses anxious, fearful,
or avoidant personality traits. For example,

those with avoidant and dependent personality
disorders often avoid meeting new people or

taking risks and show a lack of confidence,
an excessive need to be taken care of, and

a tremendous fear of being abandoned. Now,
in the past, and, to a great extent, today,

some of these categories have been controversial.
Many researchers argue that some of these

conditions overlap with each other so much
that it can be impossible to tease them apart.

Narcissistic personality disorder, for example,
has many traits that resemble histrionic personality

disorder. And because of this gray area, the
most commonly diagnosed personality disorder

is actually personality disorder not otherwise
specified or PDNOS. The prevalence of this

diagnosis suggests that while clinicians can
identify a personality disorder in a patient,

figuring out the details of the condition
can be messy and difficult.

One proposed alternative for diagnosing these
disorders is the Dimensional Model, which,

in essence, gets rid of discrete disorders
and replaces them with a range of personality

traits or symptoms, rating each person on
each dimension. So the Dimensional Model would

assess a patient not with the aim of diagnosing
one disorder or another, but instead, simply

finding out that they rank high on say, narcissism
and avoidance. It's a work in progress, so

with another generation, the clinical definition of
"personality disorder" may evolve pretty radically.

One of the best-studied personality disorders
right now is Borderline Personality Disorder,

or BPD. Borderline makes it sounds like patients
are like, pretty close to being healthy, but

not quite, but that is not at all the case.
BPD sufferers have often learned to use dysfunctional,

unhealthy ways to get their basic psychological
needs met, like love and validation, by using

things like outbursts of rage, or on the other
end of the spectrum, self-injury behaviors

like cutting or worse. People with BPD were
once commonly maligned by clinicians as 'difficult'

or 'attention-seeking', but we now understand
BPD as a complicated set of learned behaviors

and emotional responses to traumatic or neglectful
environments, particularly in childhood. In

a sense, people with this disorder learn that
rage or self-harm helped them cope with traumatic

situations, but as a result, they also end
up using them in non-traumatic situations.

Although challenging for patients and clinicians
alike, the good news is that some psychotherapies

have helped even the most severely suffering,
repeatedly hospitalized BPD patients.

But probably the most famous well-established,
and frankly, troubling personality disorder

is Antisocial Personality Disorder. Now, you've heard
of this before, but maybe by one of its now

somewhat out of vogue synonyms, "psychopathy"
or "sociopathy." People with Antisocial Personality

Disorder, usually men, exhibit a lack of conscience
for wrongdoing, even towards friends and family

members. Their destructive behavior surfaces
in childhood or adolescence, beginning with

excessive lying, fighting, stealing, violence,
or manipulation. As adults, people with this

disorder are thought to generally end up in
one of two situations: either they are unable

to keep a job and engage in violent criminal
or similarly dysfunctional behavior; or they

become clever, charming con-artists, or ruthless
executives who make their way to positions

of power. Tony Soprano would have qualified
for a diagnosis, even if he wasn't nearly

as bad as, say, serial killer Ted Bundy or
Vlad the Impaler, the infamous 15th century

Romanian prince who personally watched about
100,000 people get impaled or have the skin
of their feet licked off by goats.
Yeah. That happened.

Despite this classic remorselessness, lack
of empathy, and sometimes criminal behavior,

criminality is not always a component of antisocial
behavior. Certainly many people with criminal

records don't fit that psychopathic profile.
Most show remorse, love, and concern for friends

and family. But still, although anti-social
personalities make up just about 1% of the

general population, they were estimated in one study
to constitute about 16% of the incarcerated population.

So, how might someone end up with such a disturbing
disorder? Well, as you might expect, the causes

are probably a tangled combination of biological and
psychological threads, both genetic and environmental.

Although no one has found a single genetic
predictor of Antisocial Personality Disorder,

twin and adoption studies do show that relatives
of those with psychopathic features do have

a higher likelihood of engaging in psychopathic
behavior themselves. And early signs are sometimes

detected as young as age three or four, often
as an impairment in fear conditioning, in

other words, lower than normal response to
things that typically startle or frighten

children like loud and unpleasant noises.
Most kids only need to get burned by a hot

dish once to know to stay away, but kids who
end up displaying Antisocial Personalities

as adults don't necessarily connect or care about
the learned consequences when they're little.

From there, like we've seen in other disorders,
genetic and biological influences can intersect

with an abusive or neglectful environment
to help wire the personality in a peculiar

and damaged way. While the vast majority of
traumatized people don't grow up to be killers

or con-artists, genes do seem to predispose some
people to be more sensitive to abuse or trauma.

Meanwhile, studies exploring the neural basis
of Antisocial Disorder have revealed that

when shown evocative photographs, like a child
being hit or a woman with a knife at her throat,

those with psychopathic personality features
showed little change in heart rate and perspiration,
as compared to control groups.

And the classic antisocial lack of impulse
control and other symptoms have also been

linked to deficits in certain brain structures.
One study compared PET scans from 41 people

convicted of murder to those of non-criminals
and found that the convicted killers had greatly

reduced activity in the frontal lobe, an area
associated with impulse control and keeping

aggressive behavior in check. In fact, violent
repeat offenders had as much as 11% less frontal

lobe tissue than the average brain. Their
brains also responded less to facial displays

of stress or anguish, something that's also
observed in childhood, so it's possible that

some antisocial personalities lack empathy
because they simply don't or can't register

others' feelings. Research has also suggested
an overly reactive dopamine reward system,

suggesting that the drive to act on an impulse
to gain stimulation or short-term rewards

regardless of the consequences may be more
intense than the average person's.

As we mentioned before, because personality
disorders are pretty much egosyntonic by definition,

people don't often acknowledge that they have
a problem or a need for treatment - and in

the case of Antisocial Personality Disorder,
even if they did, there aren't many specific
treatments available, at least not for adults.

But there are some promising interventions
for kids and adolescents whose minds and brains

are more plastic and adaptable. In this way,
the best way to treat Antisocial Personality

Disorder may be in trying to prevent it. According
to American psychiatrist Donald W. Black,

among others, many kids diagnosed with Conduct
Disorder, the diagnostic precursor to Antisocial

Disorder, are at high-risk for developing
Antisocial Personalities as adults. But by

identifying warning signs early on and by
working with these kids and families to correct

their behavior and remove negative influences,
some of that impulse fearlessness could be

channeled into healthier directions, like
to reward promoting athleticism, or a spirit

of adventure. It's important to remember that
Antisocial Personality Disorder is only one

type of personality disorder. This is a diverse
family of psychological conditions determined

by many different factors and we're still
in the early stages of diagnosing and understanding
the mechanisms behind them.

Today, you learned about personality disorders
and the difference between ego-dystonic and

ego-syntonic disorders. We looked at the three
clusters of personality disorder, according

to the DSM V, and how personality disorder
symptoms often overlap. We also took a look

at Borderline and Antisocial Personality Disorders,
including their potential bio-psycho-social roots.

Thank you for watching, especially to all
of our Subbable subscribers, without whom

we could not make Crash Course. To find out
how you can become a supporter, just go to
Subbable.com/CrashCourse.

This episode was written by Kathleen Yale,
edited by Blake de Pastino, and our consultant

is Dr. Ranjit Bhagwat. Our director and editor
is Nicholas Jenkins, the script supervisor

and sound designer is Michael Aranda, and
the graphics team is Thought Cafe.
